title: Japanese submarine Ro-32
text:
Ro-32, originally named Submarine No. 71, was an <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> <a href="Kaichu%20type%20submarine">"Kaichu"-Type</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a> of the "Kaichu" V ("Toku Chu") subclass. She was in commission from 1924 to 1938, seeing service in the waters of <a href="Formosa">Formosa</a> and <a href="Japan">Japan</a>, then served as a stationary <a href="Training%20ship">training</a> <a href="Hulk%20%28ship%29">hulk</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Design and description.
The submarines of the "Kaichu" V sub-class were designed for anti-shipping operations and carried more fuel and had greater range and a heavier gun armament than preceding "Kaichu"-type submarines. They <a href="Displacement%20%28ship%29">displaced</a> surfaced and submerged. The submarines were long and had a <a href="Beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and a <a href="Draft%20%28hull%29">draft</a> of . They had a diving depth of .
For surface running, the submarines were powered by two <a href="Sulzer%20%28manufacturer%29">Sulzer</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s, each driving one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a>. When submerged each propeller was driven by a <a href="electric%20motor">electric motor</a>. They could reach on the surface and underwater. On the surface, they had a range of — although the Imperial Japanese Navy officially announced it as — at ; submerged, they had a range of at .
The submarines were armed with four internal bow <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s and carried a total of eight <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es. They were also armed with a single <a href="12%20cm/45%203rd%20Year%20Type%20naval%20gun"></a> deck gun and one 6.5 mm <a href="machine%20gun">machine gun</a>.
Construction and commissioning.
"Ro-32" was <a href="Keel-laying">laid down</a> as Submarine No. 71 on 24 October 1921 by <a href="Kawasaki%20Heavy%20Industries">Kawasaki</a> at <a href="Kobe">Kobe</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">Launched</a> on 19 March 1923, she was completed and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 31 May 1924.
Service history.
Upon commissioning, "Submarine No. 71" was attached to the <a href="Sasebo%20Naval%20District">Sasebo Naval District</a>, to which she remained attached throughout her active career. On 15 June 1924, she was assigned to both Submarine Division 25 — in which she spent her active career — and the <a href="Mako%20Defense%20Division">Mako Defense Division</a> headquartered at <a href="Magong">Mako</a> off <a href="Formosa">Formosa</a>. She was renamed Ro-32 on 1 November 1924. On 1 December 1926, she was reassigned to the <a href="Sasebo%20Defense%20Division">Sasebo Defense Division</a>, headquartered at <a href="Sasebo">Sasebo</a>, Japan. Her service in the Sasebo Defense Division ended on 15 November 1934, after which she served as a unit of Submarine Division 25 in the Sasebo Naval District. 
"Ro-32" was <a href="Ship%20decommissioning">decommissioned</a> and placed in the Fourth Reserve on 15 December 1938. The Japanese struck her from the Navy list on 1 April 1942, and that day she became a stationary <a href="Training%20ship">training</a> <a href="Hulk%20%28ship%29">hulk</a> at the submarine school at <a href="%C5%8Ctake%2C%20Hiroshima">Ōtake</a>, Japan. She was scrapped ca. August 1945.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the <a href="United%20States%20Coast%20Guard">United States Coast Guard</a> <a href="United%20States%20Coast%20Guard%20Cutter">cutter</a> , the Coast Guard-manned <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> <a href="Yard%20patrol%20boat">patrol vessel</a> , and a <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Air%20Force">Royal Canadian Air Force</a> <a href="Bristol%20Bolingbroke">Bristol Bolingbroke</a> <a href="maritime%20patrol%20aircraft">maritime patrol aircraft</a> of <a href="No.%20115%20Squadron%20RCAF">No. 115 Squadron</a> shared credit for the sinking of a submarine in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> off <a href="Southeast%20Alaska">Southeast Alaska</a> at on 9 July 1942, and in 1947 the <a href="Joint%20Army-Navy%20Assessment%20Committee">Joint Army-Navy Assessment Committee</a> identified the sunken submarine as "Ro-32". In 1967, the U.S. Navy retracted that finding after determining that "Ro-32" had been inactive in Japan at the time of the sinking and had remained afloat through the end of World War II.
